string_table.name: npnxnsnfns0001001101
string_table.string: Skip Navigation. Hit enter to return to the slide.

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript:
You have the ability to automate your reporting process by linking data from one source to multiple locations. This is made easy by the abundance of linking features available in Wdesk.

You may be used to having some sort of technical support, such as IT, help with the integration and linking of your documents; however, with Wdesk, creating links is easy. Simply copy and paste and the relationship is built.

In this module you will learn how to create links from a workbook cell to a table cell, create an in-text link, format links, modify a source link, follow that change to various destinations using the Link Properties panel, and how to share your changes so that other users can view them.

Let's create a link from a workbook to a table within a document. Notice there are a few open documents.

The first document is the workbook. The workbook contains data to link to other documents within the project. The second document is titled 10-K_12.31.2014.

Let's go to the Properties and Income section within the workbook. Here you see that the document section is set up similarly to all of the tables and any in-text sections that you may have to link to within the 10-K document.

Notice that some of the cells have blue triangles and others have green triangles in the upper left corner. These blue and green triangles indicate any links that are found within Wdesk.

Blue triangles specify that a cell is a source link. Green triangles specify that the data within the cell is linked to a source location.

Links are very important in Wdesk because they allow users to update data in one location, which then automatically updates the data in all locations where it is linked.

Links are also important if you are working in a document that requires XBRL (10Ks, 10Qs, etc). In order to apply XBRL, a link must exist.

Within the workbook you will notice blue links. Again, blue triangles indicate a source link, which is the source of information that is going to another location.

The other location is the destination link that is indicated by a green triangle. One source link can have several destination links as you will see in a moment.

Another indicator you will notice here is a green triangle in the bottom right-hand corner of the table cell. This signifies that the cell contains a formula.

Additionally you may see a red triangle in the top left corner of a cell. A red triangle signifies a broken link and should you ever see one please contact your CSM.

If you want to make a change to Furniture and Fixtures in cell B9 of the workbook you could double-click on the cell; however, a window will pop up indicating that the cell value cannot be edited, is linked, and must be edited from its source.

To view the source, click the View Source button to go to another section within the document outline, of the workbook, titled Balance Sheets.

Within the Balance Sheet notice that cell B18 - Furniture, Fixtures, and Equipment- is automatically selected.

The value within this cell is the source that is linked to multiple destinations throughout all project documents.

By having the source link located in the Balance Sheet, you can update it once and it will flow to all the other destination locations.

This means that if you need to make a change you only have to make it once, share, and know that it has been updated in all destination locations.

By accepting that change you will notice that there are several other changes that are happening automatically within this section.

The document is now back in draft mode again. In the workbook, the pencil icon appears in the document outline, the same as what you saw within the 10-K document.

Also notice the source link within cell B18, the blue triangle now has an orange underline indicating that the link is in draft mode and needs to be shared. Within the same table you can see that other formulas have been updated as well.

If you wanted to see that the change has been updated in the destination locations, you can use Link Properties. If you right-click you have the options to see Link Properties.

You can also click the link icon, in the Right Task Pane, to open the Link Properties menu.

Within the Link Properties menu you can see all of the information related to the link such as Note 4 in the workbook as well as the source link in the balance sheet, and the destination location within the 10-K document.

To verify that the destination links have been updated, hover over the 10-K_12.31.2014 document under the destination links section in Link Properties and click the "Go to link" button. Wdesk will take you to the destination link within the 10-K document.

Although the 10-K is not in draft mode, the workbook is, which means the change in the workbook needs to be shared.

Another thing you may have noticed is that these cells within the 10-K are not linked to the workbook meaning that any changes made in the workbook will not be reflected here.

To create a link lets go back to the workbook and in the document outline lets go to Note 4, Properties and Leases.

Creating a link is a simple Copy and Paste. Click and drag the mouse to select cells B10 through B15.

Right-click and select Copy from the menu. You can also use keyboard commands control C to copy and control V to paste.

Within the 10-K document, click to activate cells B6-B11, Right-click, and select Paste.

Notice that you do not see any green triangles indicating that destination links were created in cells B6 through B11. Click to open the clipboard to finish creating the links.

With the clipboard open you have various linking options to choose from. You can select values only, values and formulas, or create links from. If you select "create links from" you can choose only cells with values, all cells, or only cells with links.

Beneath that you can also choose to apply formatting. In this case you do not since the workbook doesn't show the EDGAR shading that you see in the 10-K. You can also select transpose if you need to.

Selecting Set Default will style all future links, during the same working session, with the same options that you chose here.

For this link let's select "create links from", and choose "only cells with values". Select Set Default and click Apply to connect these cells with the source location in the Workbook.

Remember that if you choose "Set Default", these options will be applied the next time you link data within the same working session.

If you click to select the newly created links and go to Link Properties, you see that the source is still from the Balance Sheet that is linked to other destination links in the workbook.

If you want to link the next row, again you can select a range of cells by clicking and dragging from cell D16 to D23, right-click, and select Copy.

Within the 10-K document click to select cells D3 through D11, right-click, and select Paste to complete the setup for this table. Notice that each cell within the range D3 through D11 has a green triangle in the upper left-hand corner.

This is because the clipboard option "Set Default" was selected from the last time a link was created.

It is common practice to create links for dates within the document so there is one place to update them within the dates page in the workbook.

Within the workbook let's navigate to the Dates and General section. Click to select cell B24, December 31, 2014 under Current Period end.

With cell B24 selected, right-click and select Copy.

Go back to the 10-K document and highlight December 31, 2014 above the table, right-click, and select Paste.

Notice that the link has automatically been created indicated by the green underline beneath the date.

If you want to only copy the value you can change that within the clipboard. Click to open the clipboard and select "Values Only" then click Apply.

Now let's link the date December 31, 2013 from the workbook to the 10-K document.

Inside the workbook click to highlight cell C24, right-click, and select Copy.

Go back to the 10-K document and highlight December 31, 2013 above the table, right-click, and select Paste.

Wdesk provides options for formatting dates. Notice that the date value format is showing up here.

If you decide to have it represent the year you can select the year value, 2012. Notice that the preview displays what the formatted date will look like in the document.

If you select the 01/05 notice now that the preview displays 12/31.

You can also choose to make it Uppercase all, Abbreviate month, or Keep as default.

There are also advanced options if you want to add a Custom prefix or Custom suffix.

Let's say you want the date to display as month and year. Select January 2012 and notice that the preview now displays the date as December 2013.

Click Apply Formatting and the linked value changes from December 31, 2013 to December 2013 within the document.

The date is still linked to the same source in the workbook but will update and appear differently within the document according to the link properties you just set.

Scrolling down, you'll notice that there are several in-text links below the table as well. In the first sentence of the third paragraph is the value 945 million dollars. This value is not linked so let's go ahead and link it to a source value in the workbook.

Click to activate the workbook and go to the Properties and Leases section.

Within the table, click to select cell B19 Total Rent Expense (millions). Notice that the value has not yet been linked.

Right-click and select Copy, then go back to the 10-K document, click to highlight 945 million, right-click, and select Paste.

Notice that the value now displays 945 million without the dollar sign. This needs to be changed to match the formatting of the other dollar amounts within the document.

Above the document you will see the link's current formatting. Notice that it is displayed in millions and is set to accounting.

To add a dollar sign, simply click the dollar sign icon and it will automatically update the linked value to display as dollar sign 945 million.

You can also format the link using the Format Link menu. Click to select the value, right-click, and select Format Links.

Within the Format Link window click to open the Symbol drop-down menu and select "$ (General Dollar).

Notice that the value previews as $945 million.

You have the option to change things such as Unit Type and Decimals. There are also Advanced options to choose from which allow you to show the number in words, adding custom suffixes and prefixes, as well as changing the symbol placement.

Click Apply Formatting so that the value displays correctly in the document.

Let's go to the Employee Stock Plan section within the 10-K to view a Source link in text.

Notice that the word five has a blue underline. This blue underline indicates that the five serves as a source link.

In this situation you can update the value directly from within the document itself.

You can also move the source to the workbook. If you click on this value, click copy. Then go to the workbook and select the cell where you want the value to be located, and click paste.

You'll want to click the clipboard and select the option of "Make Source Link" then "Apply." This will create your source in the workbook and if you go back to that location in the document, you will see that it is now a destination link.

This process is very important for any items that have XBRL associated to it. If you complete the steps you went through with the 945 million dollars, it would disconnect your XBRL.

In this module you learned how to create links from a workbook cell to a table cell, create an in-text link, format links, modify a source link, follow that change to various destinations using the Link Properties panel, and how to share your changes so that other users can view them.
